original_data.question:
A 55-year-old woman presents to the office because she has been feeling weak. For the past 2 years, she has been urinating a considerable volume every time she goes to the bathroom. She has no past medical history. Her heart rate is 86/min, respiratory rate is 15/min, temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), and blood pressure is 111/79 mm Hg. Laboratory studies are significant for the following:
Calcium 13.8 mg/dL
PTH 230 pg/mL
Her complete metabolic panel is otherwise within normal limits. Imaging studies show subperiosteal resorption and osteoporosis. Scintigraphy reveals the most common pathologic condition associated with the patient’s diagnosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

model_response:
The patient has hyperparathyroidism. The most common cause is a parathyroid adenoma. The excess PTH causes increased osteoclastic activity, which results in bone resorption and the release of calcium into the bloodstream. The increased calcium concentration inhibits the release of PTH. The renal excretion of phosphate is also decreased. The excess calcium concentration stimulates the renal enzyme 25-hydroxyvitamin D-1α hydroxylase, which converts 25-hydroxyvitamin D to 1α,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol). The calcitriol causes an increased resorption of calcium in the intestines and kidneys. The increased urination of calcium can lead to nephrocalcinosis.

The increased PTH concentration also causes an increased phosphate reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule. This results in decreased phosphate levels in the blood.

The increased PTH concentration also causes an increased osteoblastic activity, which results in the formation of osteocytic-rich areas in the bone. These areas are radiolucent and are called "brown tumors."

The increased PTH concentration also causes an increased bone turnover, which results in increased osteoblastic and osteoclastic activity. The osteoclastic activity can result in subperiosteal resorption.

The increased PTH concentration also causes an increased bone turnover, which results in increased osteoblastic and osteoclastic activity. The osteoclastic activity can result in subchondral resorption.

The increased PTH concentration also causes an increased bone turnover, which results in increased osteoblastic and osteoclastic activity. The osteoclastic activity can result in resorption of the lamina dura of the teeth.

The increased PTH concentration also causes an increased bone turnover, which results in increased osteoblastic and osteoclastic activity. The osteoclastic activity can result in resorption of the trabeculae of the bone.

The increased PTH concentration also causes an increased bone turnover, which results in increased osteoblastic and osteoclastic activity. The osteoclastic activity can result in resorption of the cortex of the bone.

The increased PTH concentration also causes an increased bone turnover, which results in increased osteoblastic and osteoclastic activity. The osteoclastic activity can result in resorption of the medullary cavity of the bone.

The increased PTH concentration also causes an increased bone turnover, which results in increased osteoblastic and osteoclastic activity. The osteoclastic activity can result in resorption of the entire bone.

The increased PTH concentration also causes an increased bone turnover, which results in increased osteoblastic and osteoclastic activity. The osteoclastic activity can result in resorption of the entire bone.

The increased PTH concentration also causes an increased bone turnover, which results in increased osteoblastic and osteoclastic activity. The osteoclastic activity can result in resorption of the entire bone.

The increased PTH concentration also causes an increased bone turnover, which results in increased osteoblastic and osteoclastic activity. The osteoclastic activity can result in resorption of the entire bone.

The increased PTH concentration also causes an increased bone turnover, which results in increased osteoblastic and osteoclastic activity. The osteoclastic activity can result in resorption of the entire bone.

The increased PTH concentration also causes an increased bone turnover, which results in increased osteoblastic and osteoclastic activity. The osteoclastic activity can result in resorption of the entire bone.

The increased PTH concentration also causes an increased bone turnover, which results in increased osteoblastic and osteoclastic activity. The osteoclastic activity can result in resorption of the entire bone.

The increased PTH concentration also causes an increased bone turnover

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Having strength, power, or intensity less than average or expected.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
The amount of three dimensional space occupied by an object or the capacity of a space or container.
The dimension of the physical universe which, at a given place, orders the sequence of events. (McGraw-Hill Dictionary of Scientific and Technical Terms, 6th ed)
Facilities containing equipment for disposal of human excrement, often with an accompanying hand-washing station.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
The number of times the HEART VENTRICLES contract per unit of time, usually per minute.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
The chemical reactions and pathways by which individual cells transform chemical substances. [GOC:go_curators]
A radiographic technique used to evaluate a specific anatomic location for a specific purpose.
Administration to periosteum, the thick, fibrous membrane covering the entire surface of a bone except its articular cartilage and the areas where it attaches to tendons and ligaments.
Bone loss due to osteoclastic activity.

Reduction of bone mass without alteration in the composition of bone, leading to fractures. Primary osteoporosis can be of two major types: postmenopausal osteoporosis (OSTEOPOROSIS, POSTMENOPAUSAL) and age-related or senile osteoporosis.

The production of an image obtained by cameras that detect the radioactive emissions of an injected radionuclide as it has distributed differentially throughout tissues in the body. The image obtained from a moving detector is called a scan, while the image obtained from a stationary camera device is called a scintiphotograph.
An abnormal structural condition of the human body, usually macroscopic, that is common to a variety of different diseases.
Joined in some kind of relationship.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
